3:24 This reaction is wrong. Just look at the 2x NH4+ on the left and only 1x NH4+ on the right of the reaction. This is ONLY the case when ammonium bicarbonate is used which is often easier to find then ammonium carbonate.

With water that have 1g/mL = x and the density of pure formic acid = 1,22 g/mL and the intermediate density on the right of the formula will give you a 2 minute calculation of the actual HCOOH concentration present by for example this formula:

(1 g/mL * x mL) + (1,22 g/mL * y mL) = measured (intermediate) density

then:
(measured density -1)/(1,22 - 1) = x or y (you can store or write that value down and see if the formula is right) but in this case this is y = # mL HCOOH
(y - 1) * (-1) = x mL H2O

Indeed, don't boil it at the end or just use a dish and let it evaporate without the nasty corrosive HCOOH smell or remove the water under vacuo.

HCOONa + NH4Cl - - > HCOONH4 + NaCl

This reaction must work as NaCl is stable.

Interesting so formamide can generate HCN fumes if strongly heated? This would be a bad thing in most cases but what if your goal was to make an alkali cyanide? Could formamide and sodium hydroxide be heated together to make sodium cyanide?

And if you ever get some Pd/C catalyst I think a cool reaction to explore would be a hydrodehalogenation reaction of aryl halides. Pd/C and ammonium formate are used and I've read a few papers where their goal was to clean up contaminated water sources that contained chlorinated compounds, specifically aryl chlorides. The subject matter would go in line with the videos you've done on DDT and other chlorinated compounds; you could do a video on a potential way of cleaning up halogenated contaminants in water.

Speaking of palladium, an interesting idea for a project might be to extract/refine/chlorinate the palladium found in old blood-glucometer test strips. Only some product lines use palladium, and it'd take quite a few strips to get a useful amount, but, it could be interesting, and it doesn't appear anyone has bothered to try on YouTube.

I must say, your videos are the most helpful thing I could have right now. Your content has a large palette of reactions and procedures; the video quality is gorgeous; and your editing is, from my perspective, perfect.
I'm studying for the Olympiad and, besides from a bunch of textbooks, I can't get any insights on the practical side of chemistry because of my high-school not having the required glassware and refusing to buy it, saying "it's expensive and risky". I was thinking of buying them myself, but lacking a source of income and being dependent financially on others makes it quite impossible.
Because of you videos, at least I get to see the behavior and the procedures for most reactions that I had learned and I'm learning.
Thank you, and I really appreciate the effort you invest into this project.

Actually palladium (II) chloride isn't that expensive right now. It used to be a lot cheaper but stil, if you look around you can find it for between $25 and $30 a gram US. And the more you get the less it is per gram.
For most reactions I've used it in I've only had to use a few grams.
Glicerol and Oxalic Acid can be used to get Formic Acid if you can't find it OTC... OTC glycerol should be easy and some stain remover and other cleaning products contain Oxalic Acid.
